thread.title: David Cameron records a Snapchat video with Schwarzenegger
thread.title_full: David Cameron records a Snapchat video with Schwarzenegger | Daily Mail Online

author: Tim Sculthorpe, Mailonline Deputy Political Editor
title: David Cameron records a Snapchat video with Schwarzenegger
text:
David Cameron has declared 'I'll be back' in a toecurling Snapchat video with Arnold Schwarzenegger.
The clip - shot by the ex-governor of California - is captioned 'with my great friend David Cameron ' and appears to be taken at a party.
After being introduced by the actor, terminated PM Mr Cameron - who appeared to be slurring his words - said: 'I'm here with the Governor, he did a great job... and I'll be back.'
As the clip ends, Schwarzenegger says 'oh... wow.'
The clip - shot by the ex-governor of California - is captioned 'with my great friend David Cameron' and appears to be taken at a party
Mr Cameron, who quit politics in September and destroying his career with defeat in the EU referendum, is currently focused on his memoirs and making speeches.
The ex Tory leader is on a lucrative speaking tour of the United States and on Tuesday spoke at the Trinity University in San Antonio.
Mr Cameron's remarks defended 'responsible capitalism' and the 'breathtaking' changes caused by globalisation.
In the UK, the ex PM caused a stir by demanding more funding for dementia research after becoming president of Alzheimer's Research UK.
He joined Schwarzenegger just days after he was mocked by US President Donald Trump for falling TV ratings after taking over the Apprentice.
At a speech, Mr Trump said: 'They hired a big, big movie star, Arnold Schwarzenegger, to take my place, and we know how that turned out.
'The ratings went right down the tubes. It's been a total disaster.
Mr Cameron welcomed Schwarzenegger to Downing Street in 2010 while the actor was Governor of California
'And Mark will never, ever bet against Trump again, and I want to just pray for Arnold, if we can, for those ratings, OK?'
The actor responded in a video clip, saying: 'Hey Donald, I have a great idea - why don't we switch jobs?
'You take over TV, because you're such an expert in ratings, and I take over your job, and then people can finally sleep comfortably again, hmm?'
The ex Tory leader is on a lucrative speaking tour of the United States and on Tuesday spoke at the Trinity University in San Antonio, pictured
Mr Cameron's remarks defended 'responsible capitalism' and the 'breathtaking' changes caused by globalisation
